title: This poppy rework article is full of inaccuracies

embed.description: Season 5 is fast approaching and we've been given some clues as to what we can expect. I've organized the major events in this article; note that while these are all confirmed, there's no timeframe, so they might not happen in 2015.

body:
So I read this article, which made several points about why Poppy is probably going to be reworked. The only thing is, some of the points are a bit off the mark. The real reason they are reworking her is probably that she is unpopular, but as a poppy main seeing all of this slander against my favorite champion annoys me greatly.

Quoting from the article:   

* However, Poppy isn’t exactly handing out counterplay tips. Her main cons – an abysmally small mana pool and lack of wave-clear – don’t give enemies an opportunity to abuse; they just keep Poppy toned down so she doesn’t dominate.

This is absolutely untrue. Poppy has clear weaknesses that are not hard to exploit, and they are fairly obvious. This article makes it sound like no waveclear and low mana are trivial, but this is not true. Minion waves will constantly be pushed into your turret, making it possible for the enemy champion to roam freely, and putting damage on the turret. Her mana pool is so low that poppy can literally run out of mana before doing enough damage to kill the enemy champion, if they have any form of sustain. Of course, in a 1v1 she would have the damage, but again, poppy can only go in at set times(determined by the minion waves which she cannot clear) so invariably the opponent has ample time to sustain back up. This weak early game is a big weakness. These weaknesses are the whole reason she is not played. If she were dominating, people would be playing her more. 

In addition to these, Poppy's other weakness is that she has several bad match-ups. Anybody with range counters her, because her only gapcloser(which costs more mana than her hammer blow) does minimal damage and pushes her into the enemy minion wave(Assuming they dont decide to randomly walk next to a wall). If poppy goes even in laning, then she has done her job.

Also, Poppy also has extremely poor pathing compared to other champions. She is the only champion I have played where you can literally permanently get stuck between a minion and a wall, until you kill the minion. This doesn't happen every game, but it happens frequently enough. even without this, you will miss more cs from being randomly pathed around than you would on another champion. 

* The main offenders are her passive and ultimate. Blocking chunks of damage innately and constantly is just raw statistical power. The enemy gets hardly any feedback, visual or number-wise, when spells hit Poppy for halved damage. It’s not really a passive you can play around in a teamfight or even in lane, unless you’ve true damage or low-cooldown spells. 

The enemy knows when poppy was saved by her passive. About every other game I hear "Poppy passive OP". If the problem is that her passive doesn't give the enemy feedback, then implement that feedback. The passive itself is very unique and well designed. 

* Worse, still, this passive defines Poppy as a bruiser, meaning her appeal lies in bad design. 

Can I please slap whoever wrote this. The passive doesn't define poppy as anything. Barring a veigar ultimate, this passive ussually only comes into use when poppy is less than 200-300 HP and about to die. If the numbers fall right, it can practically be nullified and not matter. It ussually gives her an extra autoattack or 2 of survivability, no more. Her kit is what defines her as a bruiser, not her passive. 

 * Lategame Poppy

Lategame poppy is strong. Not dominating, but strong. The problem is that when she uses her ultimate, the counterplay is to simply walk away from her. If the carry is not near a wall, she has a hard time killing them without ignite. In addition, whoever she ults can either CC her(if you ult the support), or do massive damage to her(if you ult someone else). This means poppy has to be very careful about when she goes in. The question is always "Can I catch up to the fleeing carry and do enough damage to kill them". Poppy doesn't have insane amounts of damage, and she has to stick to the carry for at least long enough to deliver 2 hammer blows(4~ second cooldown) if she wants to kill them unaided. Thinking about when to ult and who to ult is an important lategame decision that will test a player strategically. 

* Diplomatic Immunity reminds me a bit of Magic The Gathering’s Black Lotus, in that almost every Champion can replace their ultimate with Poppy’s.*

One can make an arguement that x champions ult could be swapped with y champion, and in some cases it's true. But poppy's ult suits her very well. The ult is very well named, since poppy is a diplomat, and diplomats have diplomatic immunity. The ult is very clever and goes with her kit. 

TL;DR: Please don't take the unique champion poppy is and turn her into a generic bruiser. Her current design is not bad. At the moment, she is fairly balanced, has exploitable weaknesses, and has counterplay options. All poppy needs is some QoL buffs, such as improving her pathing around minions.

If there is a rework just plz keep her Q the way it is. hitting someone in the face is what makes poppy fun.

Few things frustrate me more than fighting a mobile champ, because they come in and pick a fight with you, and the moment they realize they are outmatched, all they do is start walking toward a wall. I know exactly what they are going to do once they reach that wall, but because I have no mobility there is nothing I can do other than try to kill them before they get to that wall, i'm fighting the clock instead of my actual opponent. Many champions can't kill fast enough anymore thanks to nerfs because apparently having enough damage to do that makes them OP, but being able to pass through a wall every ten seconds is perfectly balanced. Hell they'll probably try to even stuff some mobility in Poppy's reworked kit. But i'm doubtful that Poppy will keep her identity as the deceptively strong and durable killer that we all know and love.

Champs with mobility, like Ezreal, are the ones with truly no counterplay.

"So this champion is going to come attack you, and when he realizes he is outmatched he is going start walking to a wall and if you aren't mobile that's just too bad. Oh wait, this champion went out of his way to pick a fight with you, and because he doesn't know your abilities and didn't check your items, he didn't realize he would lose until after he started attacking you. But everyone deserves second chances, which is why he gets to survive if he can reach that wall in x amount of seconds. Also damage is OP, which is why we are going to nerf non-mobile high damage champs to the point where they are incapable of killing that champ in x amount of seconds, but at the same time we are going to buff their defenses so that way it is defined as a rebalance instead of a nerf (*cough* *cough*{{champion:86}}) ."

You should go play an immobile champ (I define immobile as a champ that cannot pass a wall without flash). Because you don't have a flash with 10sec cooldown, you really learn how to assess a situation and learn combat patterns before you pick a fight. It will be satisfying, I promise your strategic skill in the game will improve significantly.

And then you will see how infuriating it is to be screwed out of a kill when someone absolutely insists on picking a fight with you, then realizes that you are capable of killing them without breaking a sweat, so they spend the next five seconds walking toward a wall, and if you can't kill them before they reach that wall well then it's your fault for not knowing how to fight.

Immobile champs are punished with death for walking into a bad situation. Meanwhile if an unskilled player fails to bother learning abilities or checking items, he gets no punishment for making a terrible decision because he can flash through a wall every 10 seconds, while the skilled player he tried to pick a fight with gets punished by not getting a kill he rightfully deserves, simply because he is an immobile champ.

I think you might be misinterpreting the article? Or maybe I'm misinterpreting it.

I don't think he is saying these are trivial weaknesses. I think he's saying that her lack of wave clear and her tiny mana pool or not interactive, dynamic forms of counterplay that both people participate in. They are not fun for either poppy or her opponent. They are just blunt, non-negotiable ways of making her weak in lane. 

>The passive itself is very unique and well designed.

I will *strongly* disagree with this. Sure, it's unique, in the sense that it is easily the most powerful passive in the game. it is not well designed in the slightest.

It's just a massive amount of free invisible health, with no gameplay or counterplay on either side. if you're fighting Poppy, you can't "bait it out" or avoid it, or work around it. It's just going to massively reduce any burst damage you deal to her when she's low on health. Are you playing a champion like Garen or Voli who relies on an execute? Tough beans, she will always take 50% damage from it the entire game with no counterplay. 

If this effect was tied into an active ability, or if it had a cooldown, or if she had to do something to trigger it, it would be fine. But she doesn't have to do anything. It doesn't change the way she plays. There's no way to "outplay" her passive. It's an unbelievably overpowered passive, and the only reason she gets away with having it is because the rest of her kit is intentionally kept weak to prevent people from playing her often.
